template.template: SCS_Template App Elasticsearch Cluster by HTTP
template.name: SCS_Template App Elasticsearch Cluster by HTTP
template.description:
The template to monitor Elasticsearch by Zabbix that work without any external scripts. It works with both standalone and cluster instances. The metrics are collected in one pass remotely using an HTTP agent. They are getting values from REST API _cluster/health, _cluster/stats, _nodes/stats requests. You can set {$ELASTICSEARCH.USERNAME} and {$ELASTICSEARCH.PASSWORD} macros in the template for using on the host level. If you use an atypical location ES API, don't forget to change the macros {$ELASTICSEARCH.SCHEME},{$ELASTICSEARCH.PORT}.
You can discuss this template or leave feedback on our forum https://www.zabbix.com/forum/zabbix-suggestions-and-feedback/399473-discussion-thread-for-official-zabbix-template-for-elasticsearch
Template tooling version used: 0.35

item.name: ES: Delayed unassigned shards
item.description: The number of shards whose allocation has been delayed by the timeout settings.

item.name: ES: Get cluster health
item.description: Returns the health status of a cluster.

item.name: ES: Get cluster stats
item.description: Returns cluster statistics.

item.name: ES: Inactive shards percentage
item.description: The ratio of inactive shards in the cluster expressed as a percentage.

item.name: ES: Number of initializing shards
item.description: The number of shards that are under initialization.

trigger.name: ES: Cluster has the initializing shards
trigger.description: The cluster has the initializing shards longer than 10 minutes.

item.name: ES: Number of data nodes
item.description: The number of nodes that are dedicated to data nodes.

item.name: ES: Number of nodes
item.description: The number of nodes within the cluster.

trigger.name: ES: The number of nodes within the cluster has decreased
ES: The number of nodes within the cluster has increased

item.name: ES: Number of pending tasks
item.description: The number of cluster-level changes that have not yet been executed.

item.name: ES: Number of relocating shards
item.description: The number of shards that are under relocation.

item.name: ES: Cluster health status
item.description: Health status of the cluster, based on the state of its primary and replica shards. Statuses are: green All shards are assigned. yellow All primary shards are assigned, but one or more replica shards are unassigned. If a node in the cluster fails, some data could be unavailable until that node is repaired. red One or more primary shards are unassigned, so some data is unavailable. This can occur briefly during cluster startup as primary shards are assigned.

trigger.name: ES: Health is RED
trigger.description: One or more primary shards are unassigned, so some data is unavailable. This can occur briefly during cluster startup as primary shards are assigned.

trigger.name: ES: Health is UNKNOWN
trigger.description: The health status of the cluster is unknown or cannot be obtained.

trigger.name: ES: Health is YELLOW
trigger.description: All primary shards are assigned, but one or more replica shards are unassigned. If a node in the cluster fails, some data could be unavailable until that node is repaired.

item.name: ES: Task max waiting in queue
item.description: The time expressed in seconds since the earliest initiated task is waiting for being performed.

item.name: ES: Number of unassigned shards
item.description: The number of shards that are not allocated.

trigger.name: ES: Cluster has the unassigned shards
trigger.description: The cluster has the unassigned shards longer than 10 minutes.

item.name: ES: Indices with shards assigned to nodes
item.description: The total number of indices with shards assigned to the selected nodes.

item.name: ES: Number of non-deleted documents
item.description: The total number of non-deleted documents across all primary shards assigned to the selected nodes. This number is based on the documents in Lucene segments and may include the documents from nested fields.

item.name: ES: Nodes with the data role
item.description: The number of selected nodes with the data role.

item.name: ES: Nodes with the ingest role
item.description: The number of selected nodes with the ingest role.

item.name: ES: Nodes with the master role
item.description: The number of selected nodes with the master role.

trigger.name: ES: Cluster has only two master nodes
trigger.description: The cluster has only two nodes with a master role and will be unavailable if one of them breaks.

item.name: ES: Total available size to JVM in all file stores
item.description: The total number of bytes available to JVM in the file stores across all selected nodes. Depending on OS or process-level restrictions, this number may be less than nodes.fs.free_in_byes. This is the actual amount of free disk space the selected Elasticsearch nodes can use.

item.name: ES: Total size of all file stores
item.description: The total size in bytes of all file stores across all selected nodes.

item.name: ES: Get nodes stats
item.description: Returns cluster nodes statistics.

item.name: ES: Cluster uptime
item.description: Uptime duration in seconds since JVM has last started.

trigger.name: ES: Cluster has been restarted (uptime < 10m)
trigger.description: Uptime is less than 10 minutes

item.name: ES: Service response time
item.description: Checks performance of the TCP service.

trigger.name: ES: Service response time is too high (over {$ELASTICSEARCH.RESPONSE_TIME.MAX.WARN} for 5m)
trigger.description: The performance of the TCP service is very low.

item.name: ES: Service status
item.description: Checks if the service is running and accepting TCP connections.

trigger.name: ES: Service is down
trigger.description: The service is unavailable or does not accept TCP connections.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Total available size
item_prototype.description: The total number of bytes available to this Java virtual machine on all file stores. Depending on OS or process level restrictions, this might appear less than fs.total.free_in_bytes. This is the actual amount of free disk space the Elasticsearch node can utilize.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Total size
item_prototype.description: Total size (in bytes) of all file stores.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Number of open HTTP connections
item_prototype.description: The number of currently open HTTP connections for the node.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Rate of HTTP connections opened
item_prototype.description: The number of HTTP connections opened for the node per second.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Flush latency
item_prototype.description: The average flush latency calculated from the available flush.total and flush.total_time_in_millis metrics.

trigger_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Flush latency is too high (over {$ELASTICSEARCH.FLUSH_LATENCY.MAX.WARN}ms for 5m)
trigger_prototype.description: If you see this metric increasing steadily, it may indicate a problem with slow disks; this problem may escalate and eventually prevent you from being able to add new information to your index.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Total number of index flushes to disk
item_prototype.description: The total number of flush operations.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Total time spent on flushing indices to disk
item_prototype.description: Total time in milliseconds spent performing flush operations.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Current indexing operations
item_prototype.description: The number of indexing operations currently running.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Indexing latency
item_prototype.description: The average indexing latency calculated from the available index_total and index_time_in_millis metrics.

trigger_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Indexing latency is too high (over {$ELASTICSEARCH.INDEXING_LATENCY.MAX.WARN}ms for 5m)
trigger_prototype.description: If the latency is increasing, it may indicate that you are indexing too many documents at the same time (Elasticsearchâ€™s documentation recommends starting with a bulk indexing size of 5 to 15 megabytes and increasing slowly from there).

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Total time spent performing indexing
item_prototype.description: Total time in milliseconds spent performing indexing operations.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Total number of indexing
item_prototype.description: The total number of indexing operations.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Time spent throttling operations
item_prototype.description: Time in seconds spent throttling operations for the last measuring span.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Time spent throttling merge operations
item_prototype.description: Time in seconds spent throttling merge operations for the last measuring span.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Time spent throttling recovery operations
item_prototype.description: Time in seconds spent throttling recovery operations for the last measuring span.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Rate of index refreshes
item_prototype.description: The number of refresh operations per second.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Time spent performing refresh
item_prototype.description: Time in seconds spent performing refresh operations for the last measuring span.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Rate of fetch
item_prototype.description: The number of fetch operations per second.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Current fetch operations
item_prototype.description: The number of fetch operations currently running.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Fetch latency
item_prototype.description: The average fetch latency calculated by sampling the total number of fetches and the total elapsed time at regular intervals.

trigger_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Fetch latency is too high (over {$ELASTICSEARCH.FETCH_LATENCY.MAX.WARN}ms for 5m)
trigger_prototype.description: The fetch phase should typically take much less time than the query phase. If you notice this metric consistently increasing, this could indicate a problem with slow disks, enriching of documents (highlighting the relevant text in search results, etc.), or requesting too many results.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Time spent performing fetch
item_prototype.description: Time in seconds spent performing fetch operations for the last measuring span.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Total time spent performing fetch
item_prototype.description: Time in milliseconds spent performing fetch operations.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Total number of fetch
item_prototype.description: The total number of fetch operations.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Rate of queries
item_prototype.description: The number of query operations per second.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Current query operations
item_prototype.description: The number of query operations currently running.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Query latency
item_prototype.description: The average query latency calculated by sampling the total number of queries and the total elapsed time at regular intervals.

trigger_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Query latency is too high (over {$ELASTICSEARCH.QUERY_LATENCY.MAX.WARN}ms for 5m)
trigger_prototype.description: If latency exceeds a threshold, look for potential resource bottlenecks, or investigate whether you need to optimize your queries.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Time spent performing query
item_prototype.description: Time in seconds spent performing query operations for the last measuring span.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Total time spent performing query
item_prototype.description: Time in milliseconds spent performing query operations.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Total number of query
item_prototype.description: The total number of query operations.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Amount of JVM heap committed
item_prototype.description: The amount of memory, in bytes, available for use by the heap.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Maximum JVM memory available for use
item_prototype.description: The maximum amount of memory, in bytes, available for use by the heap.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Amount of JVM heap currently in use
item_prototype.description: The memory, in bytes, currently in use by the heap.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Percent of JVM heap currently in use
item_prototype.description: The percentage of memory currently in use by the heap.

trigger_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Percent of JVM heap in use is critical (over {$ELASTICSEARCH.HEAP_USED.MAX.CRIT}% for 1h)
trigger_prototype.description: This indicates that the rate of garbage collection isnâ€™t keeping up with the rate of garbage creation. To address this problem, you can either increase your heap size (as long as it remains below the recommended guidelines stated above), or scale out the cluster by adding more nodes.

trigger_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Percent of JVM heap in use is high (over {$ELASTICSEARCH.HEAP_USED.MAX.WARN}% for 1h)
trigger_prototype.description: This indicates that the rate of garbage collection isnâ€™t keeping up with the rate of garbage creation. To address this problem, you can either increase your heap size (as long as it remains below the recommended guidelines stated above), or scale out the cluster by adding more nodes.

dependency.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Percent of JVM heap in use is critical (over {$ELASTICSEARCH.HEAP_USED.MAX.CRIT}% for 1h)

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Node uptime
item_prototype.description: JVM uptime in seconds.

trigger_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Node {#ES.NODE} has been restarted (uptime < 10m)

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Refresh thread pool active threads
item_prototype.description: The number of active threads in the refresh thread pool.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Refresh thread pool executor tasks completed
item_prototype.description: The number of tasks completed by the refresh thread pool executor.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Refresh thread pool tasks in queue
item_prototype.description: The number of tasks in queue for the refresh thread pool.

trigger_prototype.description: The number of tasks rejected by the refresh thread pool executor is over 0 for 5m.

trigger_prototype.description: The number of tasks rejected by the search thread pool executor is over 0 for 5m.

template.name: SCS_Template App Memcached
template.description:
Get Memcached metrics from plugin for the New Zabbix Agent (zabbix-agent2).
You can discuss this template or leave feedback on our forum https://www.zabbix.com/forum/zabbix-suggestions-and-feedback/398623-discussion-thread-for-official-zabbix-template-memcached
Template tooling version used: 0.35

item.name: Memcached: Commands: FLUSH per second
item.description: The flush_all command invalidates all items in the database. This operation incurs a performance penalty and shouldnâ€™t take place in production, so check your debug scripts.

item.name: Memcached: Commands: GET per second
item.description: Number of GET requests received by server per second.

item.name: Memcached: Commands: SET per second
item.description: Number of SET requests received by server per second.

item.name: Memcached: Maximum number of bytes
item.description: Maximum number of bytes allowed in cache. You can adjust this setting via a config file or the command line while starting your Memcached server.

item.name: Memcached: Open connections
item.description: The number of clients presently connected

item.name: Memcached: Max connections
item.description: Max number of concurrent connections

item.name: Memcached: Queued connections per second
item.description: Number of times that memcached has hit its connections limit and disabled its listener

trigger.name: Memcached: Too many queued connections (over {$MEMCACHED.CONN.QUEUED.MAX.WARN} in 5m)
trigger.description: The max number of connections is reachedand and a new connection had to wait in the queue as a result.

item.name: Memcached: New connections per second
item.description: Number of connections opened per second

item.name: Memcached: Connection structures
item.description: Number of connection structures allocated by the server

item.name: Memcached: Throttled connections
item.description: Number of times a client connection was throttled. When sending GETs in batch mode and the connection contains too many requests (limited by -R parameter) the connection might be throttled to prevent starvation.

trigger.name: Memcached: Too many throttled connections (over {$MEMCACHED.CONN.THROTTLED.MAX.WARN} in 5m)
trigger.description: Number of times a client connection was throttled is too hight. When sending GETs in batch mode and the connection contains too many requests (limited by -R parameter) the connection might be throttled to prevent starvation.

item.name: Memcached: CPU sys
item.description: System CPU consumed by the Memcached server

trigger.name: Memcached: Failed to fetch info data (or no data for 30m)
trigger.description: Zabbix has not received data for items for the last 30 minutes

item.name: Memcached: CPU user
item.description: User CPU consumed by the Memcached server

trigger.name: Memcached: Service is down

item.name: Memcached: Process id
item.description: PID of the server process

item.name: Memcached: Bytes used
item.description: Current number of bytes used to store items.

item.name: Memcached: Read bytes per second
item.description: The network's read rate per second in B/sec

item.name: Memcached: Written bytes per second
item.description: The network's read rate per second in B/sec

item.name: Memcached: Current number of items stored
item.description: Current number of items stored by this instance.

item.name: Memcached: Evictions per second
item.description: "An eviction is when an item that still has time to live is removed from the cache because a brand new item needs to be allocated. The item is selected with a pseudo-LRU mechanism. A high number of evictions coupled with a low hit rate means your application is setting a large number of keys that are never used again."

item.name: Memcached: Hits per second
item.description: Number of successful GET requests (items requested and found) per second.

item.name: Memcached: Misses per second
item.description: Number of missed GET requests (items requested but not found) per second.

item.name: Memcached: Threads
item.description: Number of worker threads requested

item.name: Memcached: New items per second
item.description: Number of new items stored per second.

item.name: Memcached: Uptime
item.description: Number of seconds since Memcached server start

trigger.name: Memcached: has been restarted (uptime < 10m)
trigger.description: Uptime is less than 10 minutes

item.name: Memcached: Memcached version
item.description: Version of the Memcached server

trigger.name: Memcached: Version has changed (new version: {ITEM.VALUE})
trigger.description: Memcached version has changed. Ack to close.

macro.description: Maximum number of queued connections per second
Maximum number of throttled connections per second

Connection string in the URI format (password is not used). This param overwrites a value configured in the "Plugins.Memcached.Uri" option of the configuration file (if it's set), otherwise, the plugin's default value is used: "tcp://localhost:11211"

template.name: SCS_Template DB MySQL
template.description:
Requirements for template operation: 1. Create MySQL user for monitoring. For example: CREATE USER 'zbx_monitor'@'%' IDENTIFIED BY '<password>'; GRANT USAGE,REPLICATION CLIENT,PROCESS,SHOW DATABASES,SHOW VIEW ON *.* TO 'zbx_monitor'@'%'; For more information please read the MYSQL documentation https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/grant.html. 2. Set in the {$MYSQL.DSN} macro the data source name of the MySQL instance either session name from Zabbix agent 2 configuration file or URI <protocol(host:port or /path/to/socket)/>. Examples: MySQL1, tcp://localhost:3306, tcp://172.16.0.10, unix:/var/run/mysql.sock For more information about MySQL Unix socket file please read the MySQL documentation https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/problems-with-mysql-sock.html. 3. If you had set URI in the {$MYSQL.DSN}, please define the user name and password in host macros ({$MYSQL.USER} and {$MYSQL.PASSWORD}). Leave macros {$MYSQL.USER} and {$MYSQL.PASSWORD} empty if you use a session name. Set the user name and password in the Plugins.Mysql.<...> section of your Zabbix agent 2 configuration file. For more information about configuring the Zabbix MySQL plugin please read the documentation https://git.zabbix.com/projects/ZBX/repos/zabbix/browse/src/go/plugins/mysql/README.md.
You can discuss this template or leave feedback on our forum https://www.zabbix.com/forum/zabbix-suggestions-and-feedback/384189-discussion-thread-for-official-zabbix-template-db-mysql
Template tooling version used: 0.36

item.name: MySQL: Aborted clients per second
item.description: The number of connections that were aborted because the client died without closing the connection properly.

item.name: MySQL: Aborted connections per second
item.description: The number of failed attempts to connect to the MySQL server.

trigger.name: MySQL: Server has aborted connections (over {$MYSQL.ABORTED_CONN.MAX.WARN} for 5m)
trigger.description: The number of failed attempts to connect to the MySQL server is more thanÂ {$MYSQL.ABORTED_CONN.MAX.WARN} in the last 5 minutes.

item.name: MySQL: Buffer pool efficiency
item.description: The item shows how effectively the buffer pool is serving reads.

item.name: MySQL: Buffer pool utilization
item.description: Ratio of used to total pages in the buffer pool.

trigger.name: MySQL: Buffer pool utilization is too low (less {$MYSQL.BUFF_UTIL.MIN.WARN}% for 5m)
trigger.description: The buffer pool utilization is less thanÂ {$MYSQL.BUFF_UTIL.MIN.WARN}% in the last 5 minutes. This means that there is a lot of unused RAM allocated for the buffer pool, which you can easily reallocate at the moment.

item.name: MySQL: Bytes received
item.description: The number of bytes received from all clients.

item.name: MySQL: Bytes sent
item.description: The number of bytes sent to all clients.

item.name: MySQL: Command Delete per second
item.description: The Com_delete counter variable indicates the number of times the delete statement has been executed.

item.name: MySQL: Command Insert per second
item.description: The Com_insert counter variable indicates the number of times the insert statement has been executed.

item.name: MySQL: Command Select per second
item.description: The Com_select counter variable indicates the number of times the select statement has been executed.

item.name: MySQL: Command Update per second
item.description: The Com_update counter variable indicates the number of times the update statement has been executed.

item.name: MySQL: Connections per second
item.description: The number of connection attempts (successful or not) to the MySQL server.

item.name: MySQL: Connection errors accept per second
item.description: Number of errors that occurred during calls to accept() on the listening port.

item.name: MySQL: Connection errors internalÂ per second
item.description: Number of refused connections due to internal server errors, for example out of memory errors, or failed thread starts.

item.name: MySQL: Connection errors max connectionsÂ per second
item.description: Number of refused connections due to the max_connections limit being reached.

trigger.name: MySQL: Refused connections (max_connections limit reached)
trigger.description: Number of refused connections due to the max_connections limit being reached.

item.name: MySQL: Connection errors peer addressÂ per second
item.description: Number of errors while searching for the connecting client IP address.

item.name: MySQL: Connection errors selectÂ per second
item.description: Number of errors during calls to select() or poll() on the listening port. The client would not necessarily have been rejected in these cases.

item.name: MySQL: Connection errors tcpwrapÂ per second
item.description: Number of connections the libwrap library refused.

item.name: MySQL: Created tmp tables on disk per second
item.description: The number of internal on-disk temporary tables created by the server while executing statements.

trigger.name: MySQL: Number of on-disk temporary tables created per second is high (over {$MYSQL.CREATED_TMP_DISK_TABLES.MAX.WARN} for 5m)
trigger.description: Possibly the application using the database is in need of query optimization.

item.name: MySQL: Created tmp files on disk per second
item.description: How many temporary files mysqld has created.

trigger.name: MySQL: Number of temporary files created per second is high (over {$MYSQL.CREATED_TMP_FILES.MAX.WARN} for 5m)
trigger.description: Possibly the application using the database is in need of query optimization.

item.name: MySQL: Created tmp tables on memory per second
item.description: The number of internal temporary tables created by the server while executing statements.

trigger.name: MySQL: Number of internal temporary tables created per second is high (over {$MYSQL.CREATED_TMP_TABLES.MAX.WARN} for 5m)
trigger.description: Possibly the application using the database is in need of query optimization.

item.name: MySQL: Get status variables
item.description: The item gets server global status information.

item.name: MySQL: InnoDB buffer pool pages free
item.description: The total size of the InnoDB buffer pool, in pages.

item.name: MySQL: InnoDB buffer pool pages total
item.description: The total size of the InnoDB buffer pool, in pages.

item.name: MySQL: InnoDB buffer pool reads
item.description: The number of logical reads that InnoDB could not satisfy from the buffer pool, and had to read directly from disk.

item.name: MySQL: InnoDB buffer pool reads per second
item.description: The number of logical reads per second that InnoDB could not satisfy from the buffer pool, and had to read directly from disk.

item.name: MySQL: InnoDB buffer pool read requests
item.description: The number of logical read requests.

item.name: MySQL: InnoDB buffer pool read requests per second
item.description: The number of logical read requests per second.

item.name: MySQL: InnoDB row lock time
item.description: The total time spent in acquiring row locks for InnoDB tables, in milliseconds.

item.name: MySQL: InnoDB row lock time max
item.description: The maximum time to acquire a row lock for InnoDB tables, in milliseconds.

item.name: MySQL: InnoDB row lock waits
item.description: The number of times operations on InnoDB tables had to wait for a row lock.

item.name: MySQL: Max used connections
item.description: The maximum number of connections that have been in use simultaneously since the server started.

trigger.name: MySQL: Service is down

item.name: MySQL: Queries per second
item.description: The number of statements executed by the server. This variable includes statements executed within stored programs, unlike the Questions variable.

item.name: MySQL: Questions per second
item.description: The number of statements executed by the server. This includes only statements sent to the server by clients and not statements executed within stored programs, unlike the Queries variable.

item.name: MySQL: Slow queries per second
item.description: The number of queries that have taken more than long_query_time seconds.

trigger.name: MySQL: Server has slow queries (over {$MYSQL.SLOW_QUERIES.MAX.WARN} for 5m)
trigger.description: The number of slow queries is more thanÂ {$MYSQL.SLOW_QUERIES.MAX.WARN} in the last 5 minutes.

item.name: MySQL: Threads cached
item.description: The number of threads in the thread cache.

item.name: MySQL: Threads connected
item.description: The number of currently open connections.

item.name: MySQL: Threads created per second
item.description: The number of threads created to handle connections. If Threads_created is big, you may want to increase the thread_cache_size value. The cache miss rate can be calculated as Threads_created/Connections.

item.name: MySQL: Threads running
item.description: The number of threads that are not sleeping.

item.name: MySQL: Uptime
item.description: The number of seconds that the server has been up.

trigger.name: MySQL: Failed to fetch info data (or no data for 30m)
trigger.description: Zabbix has not received data for items for the last 30 minutes.

trigger.name: MySQL: Service has been restarted (uptime < 10m)
trigger.description: MySQL uptime is less than 10 minutes.

trigger.name: MySQL: Version has changed (new version value received: {ITEM.VALUE})
trigger.description: MySQL version has changed. Ack to close.

discovery_rule.name: Replication discovery
discovery_rule.description: IfÂ "show slave status" returns Master_Host, "Replication: *" items are created.

item_prototype.name: MySQL: Replication Slave status {#MASTER_HOST}
item_prototype.description: The item gets status information on essential parameters of the slave threads.

item_prototype.name: MySQL: Replication Seconds Behind Master {#MASTER_HOST}
item_prototype.description: The number of seconds that the slave SQL thread is behind processing the master binary log. A high number (or an increasing one) can indicate that the slave is unable to handle events from the master in a timely fashion.

trigger_prototype.name: MySQL: Replication lag is too high (over {$MYSQL.REPL_LAG.MAX.WARN} for 5m)

item_prototype.name: MySQL: Replication Slave IO Running {#MASTER_HOST}
item_prototype.description: Whether the I/O thread for reading the master's binary log is running. Normally, you want this to be Yes unless you have not yet started replication or have explicitly stopped it with STOP SLAVE.

trigger_prototype.name: MySQL: The slave I/O thread is not connected to a replication master

dependency.name: MySQL: The slave I/O thread is not running

trigger_prototype.name: MySQL: The slave I/O thread is not running
trigger_prototype.description: Whether the I/O thread for reading the master's binary log is running.

item_prototype.name: MySQL: Replication Slave SQL Running {#MASTER_HOST}
item_prototype.description: Whether the SQL thread for executing events in the relay log is running. As with the I/O thread, this should normally be Yes.

trigger_prototype.name: MySQL: The SQL thread is not running
trigger_prototype.description: Whether the SQL thread for executing events in the relay log is running.

dependency.name: MySQL: The slave I/O thread is not running

trigger.name: ES: Cluster does not have enough space for resharding
trigger.description: There is not enough disk space for index resharding.

trigger.name: Memcached: Memory usage is too high (over {$MEMCACHED.MEM.PUSED.MAX.WARN} in 5m)

trigger.description: When the number of connections reaches the value of the "max_connections" parameter, new connections will be rejected.
